member.name: T:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle
member.summary: Represents a unit independent angle using a single-precision floating-point internal representation.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Degree
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single degree.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Minute
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single minute.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Second
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single second.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Radian
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single radian.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Milliradian
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single milliradian.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Gradian
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single gradian.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.radians
member.summary: The internal representation of the angle.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.#ctor(System.Single,Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleType)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SharpDX.AngleSingle structure with the given unit dependant angle and unit type.
member.param: A unit dependant measure of the angle.
The type of unit the angle argument is.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SharpDX.AngleSingle structure using the arc length formula (θ = s/r).

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Wrap
member.summary: Wraps this SharpDX.AngleSingle to be in the range [π, -π].

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.WrapPositive
member.summary: Wraps this SharpDX.AngleSingle to be in the range [0, 2π).

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Revolutions
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of revolutions this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Degrees
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Minutes
member.summary: Gets or sets the minutes component of the degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. When setting the minutes, if the value is in the range (-60, 60) the whole degrees are not changed; otherwise, the whole degrees may be changed. Fractional values may set the seconds component.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Seconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the seconds of the degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. When setting the seconds, if the value is in the range (-60, 60) the whole minutes or whole degrees are not changed; otherwise, the whole minutes or whole degrees may be changed.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Radians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of radians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Milliradians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of milliradians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. One milliradian is equal to 1/(2000π).

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.Gradians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of gradians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.IsRight
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a right angle (i.e. 90° or π/2).

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.IsStraight
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a straight angle (i.e. 180° or π).

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.IsFullRotation
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a full rotation angle (i.e. 360° or 2π).

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.IsOblique
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an oblique angle (i.e. is not 90° or a multiple of 90°).

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Mathematics.AngleSingle.IsAcute
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an acute angle (i.e. less than 90° but greater than 0°).

member.returns: The 8 corners of the frustum

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Collision.RayIntersectsPoint(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Ray@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a point.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Collision.RayIntersectsRay(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Ray@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Ray@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Collision.RayIntersectsTriangle(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Ray@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triangle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersected.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3.UpperTriangularForm(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4.Orthogonalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4.UpperTriangularForm(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular matrix.
member.remarks: If the matrix is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the matrix represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4.ReducedRowEchelonForm(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into reduced row echelon form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into reduced row echelon form.
The fifth column of the matrix.
When the method completes, contains the resultant matrix after the operation.
When the method completes, contains the resultant fifth column of the matrix.

remarks.para: The fifth column is often called the augmented part of the matrix. This is because the fifth column is really just an extension of the matrix so that there is a place to put all of the non-zero components after the operation is complete.
Often times the resultant matrix will the identity matrix or a matrix similar to the identity matrix. Sometimes, however, that is not possible and numbers other than zero and one may appear.

This method can be used to solve systems of linear equations. Upon completion of this method, the will contain the solution for the system. It is up to the user to analyze both the input and the result to determine if a solution really exists.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2.DistanceSquared(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2.Orthogonalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2[],Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2.Orthonormalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2[],Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2.TransformCoordinate(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2.TransformNormal(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3.DistanceSquared(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3.Orthogonalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3[],Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3.Orthonormalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3[],Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3.TransformNormal(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Matrix4x4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.remarks: may be preferred when only the relative distance is needed and speed is of the essence.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4.DistanceSquared(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4@,Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4.Orthogonalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4[],Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4.Orthonormalize(Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4[],Dreamcast.Mathematics.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.exception: Only non-CLR coroutines can be resumed with this overload of the Resume method. Use the overload accepting a ScriptExecutionContext instead

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Coroutine.AsUnityCoroutine
member.summary: The purpose of this method is to convert a Dreamcast.Lua/Lua coroutine to a Unity3D coroutine. This loops over the coroutine, discarding returned values, and returning null for each invocation. This means however that the coroutine will be invoked each frame. Only non-CLR coroutines can be resumed with this method. Use an overload of the Resume method accepting a ScriptExecutionContext instead.
member.exception: Only non-CLR coroutines can be resumed with this overload of the Resume method. Use the overload accepting a ScriptExecutionContext instead

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.DynValue.NewTailCallReq(Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.DynValue,Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.DynValue[])
member.summary: Creates a new request for a tail call. This is the preferred way to execute Lua/Dreamcast.Lua code from a callback, although it's not always possible to use it. When a function (callback or script closure) returns a TailCallRequest, the bytecode processor immediately executes the function contained in the request. By executing script in this way, a callback function ensures it's not on the stack anymore and thus a number of functionality (state savings, coroutines, etc) keeps working at full power.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.DynValue.NewTailCallReq(Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.TailCallData)
member.summary: Creates a new request for a tail call. This is the preferred way to execute Lua/Dreamcast.Lua code from a callback, although it's not always possible to use it. When a function (callback or script closure) returns a TailCallRequest, the bytecode processor immediately executes the function contained in the request. By executing script in this way, a callback function ensures it's not on the stack anymore and thus a number of functionality (state savings, coroutines, etc) keeps working at full power.
member.param: The data for the tail call.

member.summary: Creates a new request for a yield of the current coroutine.

member.summary: A base class for many Dreamcast.Lua objects. Helds a ReferenceID property which gets a different value for every object instance, for debugging purposes. member.summary: No type validation specific behaviour

member.summary: Nil and Void values are allowed (and returned by the call)

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.TypeValidationFlags.AutoConvert
member.summary: Simple autoconversions are attempted: 1) Numbers are convertible to strings 2) Strings are convertible to numbers if they contain a number 3) Everything is convertible to boolean (with void and nil converting to 'false', everything else converting to 'true') Note: if both AutoConvert and AllowNil are specified, nils will NOT be converted to false booleans.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.TypeValidationFlags.Default
member.summary: The default : Autoconverting values, no nils.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Debugging.IDebugger.IsPauseRequested
member.summary: Called by the script engine at execution time to check if a break has been requested. Should return pretty fast as it's called A LOT.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Debugging.IDebugger.SignalRuntimeException(Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptRuntimeException)
member.summary: Called by the script engine when a runtime error occurs. The debugger can return true to signal the engine that it wants to break into the source of the error. If it does so, it should also return true to subsequent calls to IsPauseRequested().
member.returns: True if this error should break execution.

member.summary: Called by the script engine to get what action to do next.
member.returns: T

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Debugging.IDebugger.SignalExecutionEnded
member.summary: Called by the script engine when the execution ends.

member.summary: Called by the script engine to update watches of a given type. Note that this method is not called only for watches in the strictest term, but also for the stack, etc.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptRuntimeException.BadArgumentNoValue(System.Int32,System.String,Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.DataType)
member.summary: Creates a ScriptRuntimeException with a predefined error message specifying that a function was called with no value when a value was required. This function creates a message like "bad argument #xxx to 'yyy' (zzz expected, got no value)" while creates a message like "bad argument #xxx to 'yyy' (value expected)"
member.param: Name of the function generating this error.
member.returns: The exception to be raised.

member.returns: The exception to be raised.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.BasicDescriptors.DispatchingUserDataDescriptor.MetaIndex(Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Script,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Gets a "meta" operation on this userdata. If a descriptor does not support this functionality, it should return "null" (not a nil). See for further details. If a method exists marked with for the specific metamethod requested, that method is returned. If the above fails, the following dispatching occur: __add, __sub, __mul, __div, __mod and __unm are dispatched to C# operator overloads (if they exist) __eq is dispatched to System.Object.Equals. __lt and __le are dispatched IComparable.Compare, if the type implements IComparable or IComparable{object} __len is dispatched to Length and Count properties, if those exist. __iterator is handled if the object implements IEnumerable or IEnumerator. __tonumber is dispatched to implicit or explicit conversion operators to standard numeric types. __tobool is dispatched to an implicit or explicit conversion operator to bool. If that fails, operator true is used. The script originating the request The object (null if a static request is done) The name of the metamember.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.IGeneratorUserDataDescriptor
member.summary: An interface for type descriptors having the ability to generate other descriptors on the fly.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.IGeneratorUserDataDescriptor.Generate(System.Type)
member.summary:
Generates a new descriptor for the specified type. The purpose is to allow a mechanism by which a type descriptor can replace itself with another descriptor for a specific type. For example, descriptors can be created on the fly to support generic types through this mechanism. The return value should be: null - if this descriptor is simply skipped for the specified type this - acts as if the descriptor was a vanilla descriptor a new descriptor - if a new descriptor should be used in place of this one It's recommended that instances of descriptors are cached for future references. One possible way, to do the caching is to have the generator register the descriptor through . In that case, it should query whether the type is exactly registered, through
NOTE-1 : the search for descriptors does NOT stop with the descriptor returned by this type, but other descriptors (e.g. for interfaces) might still be added. NOTE-2 : the descriptor generation mechanism is not triggered on an exact match of types. NOTE-3 : the method is called in the context of a lock over the descriptors registry so no unpredictable changes to the registry can come from other threads during the execution of this method. However this method should not take other locks, to avoid deadlocks.
member.returns: Null, this object instance or a new descriptor.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.InteropRegistrationPolicy.Explicit
member.summary: The default registration policy used by Dreamcast.Lua unless explicitely replaced. Deregistrations are allowed, but registration of a new descriptor are not allowed if a descriptor is already registered for that type. Types must be explicitly registered.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.InteropRegistrationPolicy.Automatic
member.summary: Types are automatically registered if not found in the registry. This is easier to use but potentially unsafe.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.LuaStateInterop.LuaBase
M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.LuaStateInterop.LuaBase.LuaCall(Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.LuaStateInterop.LuaState,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls a function. To call a function you must use the following protocol: first, the function to be called is pushed onto the stack; then, the arguments to the function are pushed in direct order; that is, the first argument is pushed first. Finally you call lua_call; nargs is the number of arguments that you pushed onto the stack. All arguments and the function value are popped from the stack when the function is called. The function results are pushed onto the stack when the function returns. The number of results is adjusted to nresults, unless nresults is LUA_MULTRET. In this case, all results from the function are pushed. Lua takes care that the returned values fit into the stack space. The function results are pushed onto the stack in direct order (the first result is pushed first), so that after the call the last result is on the top of the stack.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Interop.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Namespace containing classes used to customize and support advanced interoperations between scripts and CLR code.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode
member.summary: Enumerations of the possible strategies to marshal CLR objects to Dreamcast.Lua userdata and functions when using automatic descriptors. Note that these are "hints" and Dreamcast.Lua is free to ignore the access mode specified (if different from HideMembers) and downgrade the access mode to "Reflection". This particularly happens when running on AOT platforms like iOS. See also : and .

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.Reflection
member.summary: Optimization is not performed and reflection is used everytime to access members. This is the slowest approach but saves a lot of memory if members are seldomly used.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.LazyOptimized
member.summary: Optimization is done on the fly the first time a member is accessed. This saves memory for all members that are never accessed, at the cost of an increased script execution time.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.Preoptimized
member.summary: Optimization is done at registration time.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.BackgroundOptimized
member.summary: Optimization is done in a background thread which starts at registration time. If a member is accessed before optimization is completed, reflection is used.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.Hardwired
member.summary: Use the hardwired descriptor(s)

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.HideMembers
member.summary: No optimization is done, and members are not accessible at all.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.NoReflectionAllowed
member.summary: No reflection is allowed, nor code generation. This is used as a safeguard when registering types which should not use a standard reflection based descriptor - for example for types implementing

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.InteropAccessMode.Default
member.summary: Use the default access mode

member.summary: Gets a "meta" operation on this userdata. If a descriptor does not support this functionality, it should return "null" (not a nil). These standard metamethods can be supported (the return value should be a function accepting the classic parameters of the corresponding metamethod): __add, __sub, __mul, __div, __div, __pow, __unm, __eq, __lt, __le, __lt, __len, __concat, __pairs, __ipairs, __iterator, __call These standard metamethods are supported through other calls for efficiency: __index, __newindex, __tostring
member.param: The object (null if a static request is done)

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.IO.UndisposableStream
member.summary: An adapter over Stream which bypasses the Dispose and Close methods. Used to work around the pesky wrappers .NET has over Stream (BinaryReader, StreamWriter, etc.) which think they own the Stream and close them when they shouldn't. Damn.

member.summary: Opens a file for reading the script code. It can return either a string, a byte[] or a Stream. If a byte[] is returned, the content is assumed to be a serialized (dumped) bytecode. member.returns: A string, a byte[] or a Stream.

The resolution happens first on paths included in the LUA_PATH global variable (if and only if the IgnoreLuaPathGlobal is false), and - if the variable does not exist - by consulting the ScriptOptions.ModulesPaths array. Override to provide a different behaviour.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.LuaModuleAttribute
member.summary: Marks a CLR type to be a Dreamcast.Lua module. Modules are the fastest way to bring interop between scripts and CLR code, albeit at the cost of a very increased complexity in writing them. Modules is what's used for the standard library, for maximum efficiency. Modules are basically classes containing only static methods, with the callback function signature. See and for (extension) methods used to register modules to a table. See for information regarding the standard callback signature along with easier ways to marshal methods. See for easier object marshalling.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.LuaModuleAttribute.Namespace
member.summary: Gets or sets the namespace, that is the name of the table which will contain the defined functions. Can be null to be in the global table.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.LuaModuleConstantAttribute
member.summary: In a module type, mark fields with this attribute to have them exposed as a module constant. See for more information about modules.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.LuaModuleConstantAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the constant - if different from the name of the field itself

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.LuaModuleMethodAttribute
member.summary: In a module type, mark methods or fields with this attribute to have them exposed as module functions. Methods must have the signature "public static DynValue ...(ScriptExecutionContextCallbackArguments)". Fields must be static or const strings, with an anonymous Lua function inside. See for more information about modules.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.LuaModuleMethodAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the function in the module (defaults to member name)

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Namespace containing all the most commonly used classes for Dreamcast.Lua operation. When in doubt, refer to and classes as starting points.

member.summary: Namespace containing classes used to customize how the interfacing with the operative system happens for the 'os' and 'io' modules, and for future modules/classes which may require OS access. See and .

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Platforms.IPlatformAccessor
member.summary: Interface to abstract all accesses made to the underlying platform (OS, framework) by the scripting engine. Can be used both to support "non-standard" platforms (i.e. non-posix, non-windows) and/or to sandbox the behaviour of the scripting engine. It's recommended that no class implement IPlatformAccessor directly, and rather extend .

member.summary: Filters the CoreModules enumeration to exclude non-supported operations
member.returns: The requested modules, with unsupported modules filtered out.

member.summary: Gets an environment variable. Must be implemented, but an implementation is allowed to always return null if a more meaningful implementation cannot be achieved or is not desired.
member.returns: The environment variable value, or null if not found

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Platforms.IPlatformAccessor.IsRunningOnAOT

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.REPL.ReplInterpreterScriptLoader
member.summary: A script loader loading scripts directly from the file system (does not go through platform object) AND starts with module paths taken from environment variables (again, not going through the platform object). The paths are preconstructed using : * The MOONSHARP_PATH environment variable if it exists * The LUA_PATH_5_2 environment variable if MOONSHARP_PATH does not exists * The LUA_PATH environment variable if LUA_PATH_5_2 and MOONSHARP_PATH do not exists * The "?;?.lua" path if all the above fail Also, everytime a module is require(d), the "LUA_PATH" global variable is checked. If it exists, those paths will be used to load the module instead of the global ones.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.REPL.ReplInterpreterScriptLoader.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.REPL.ReplInterpreterScriptLoader.ResolveModuleName(System.String,Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Table)
member.summary: Resolves the name of a module to a filename (which will later be passed to OpenScriptFile). The resolution happens first on paths included in the LUA_PATH global variable, and - if the variable does not exist - by consulting the ScriptOptions.ModulesPaths array. Override to provide a different behaviour.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ColonOperatorBehaviour
member.summary: Defines behaviour of the colon ':' operator in CLR callbacks. Default behaviour is for ':' being treated the same as a '.' if the functions is implemented on the CLR side (e.g. in C#).

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ColonOperatorBehaviour.TreatAsDot
member.summary: The colon is treated the same as the dot ('.') operator.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ColonOperatorBehaviour.TreatAsDotOnUserData
member.summary: The colon is treated the same as the dot ('.') operator if the first argument is userdata, as a Lua colon operator otherwise.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ColonOperatorBehaviour.TreatAsColon
member.summary: The colon is treated in the same as the Lua colon operator works.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.FuzzySymbolMatchingBehavior
member.summary: A flag that controls if/how symbols (method, property, userdata) are fuzzily matched when they do not exist. Flags can be combined for multiple checks.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.FuzzySymbolMatchingBehavior.None
member.summary: No fuzzy matching is performed.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.FuzzySymbolMatchingBehavior.UpperFirstLetter
member.summary: The first letter of a symbol will be uppercased (to check for common C# naming conventions). For example, testMethod() becomes TestMethod()

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.FuzzySymbolMatchingBehavior.Camelify
member.summary: Underscores in symbols are converted to camelcase. For example, test_method() becomes testMethod()

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.FuzzySymbolMatchingBehavior.PascalCase
member.summary: Converts a symbol to pascal case. For example, test_Method_two() becomes TestMethodTwo()

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Script.Registry
member.summary: Dreamcast.Lua (like Lua itself) provides a registry, a predefined table that can be used by any CLR code to store whatever Lua values it needs to store. Any CLR code can store data into this table, but it should take care to choose keys that are different from those used by other libraries, to avoid collisions. Typically, you should use as key a string GUID, a string containing your library name, or a userdata with the address of a CLR object in your code.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.UseLuaErrorLocations
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether error messages will use Lua error locations instead of Dreamcast.Lua improved ones. Use this for compatibility with legacy Lua code which parses error messages.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.ColonOperatorClrCallbackBehaviour
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which dictates the behaviour of the colon (':') operator in callbacks to CLR code.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.Stdin
member.summary: Gets or sets the stream used as stdin. If null, a default stream is used.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.Stdout
member.summary: Gets or sets the stream used as stdout. If null, a default stream is used.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.Stderr
member.summary: Gets or sets the stream used as stderr. If null, a default stream is used.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.TailCallOptimizationThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the stack depth threshold at which Dreamcast.Lua starts doing tail call optimizations. TCOs can provide the little benefit of avoiding stack overflows in corner case scenarios, at the expense of losing debug information and error stack traces in all other, more common scenarios. Dreamcast.Lua choice is to start performing TCOs only after a certain threshold of stack usage is reached - by default half the current stack depth (128K entries), thus 64K entries, on either the internal stacks. Set this to int.MaxValue to disable TCOs entirely, or to 0 to always have TCOs enabled.

member.name: P:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.ScriptOptions.CheckThreadAccess
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the thread check is enabled. A "lazy" thread check is performed everytime execution is entered to ensure that no two threads calls Dreamcast.Lua execution concurrently. However 1) the check is performed best effort (thus, it might not detect all issues) and 2) it might trigger in very odd legal situations (like, switching threads inside a CLR-callback without actually having concurrency. Disable this option if the thread check is giving problems in your scenario, but please check that you are not calling Dreamcast.Lua execution concurrently as it is not supported.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Lua.Interpreter.Serialization.Json.JsonTableConverter
member.summary: Class performing conversions between Tables and Json. NOTE : the conversions are done respecting json syntax but using Lua constructs. This means mostly that: 1) Lua string escapes can be accepted while they are not technically valid JSON, and viceversa 2) Null values are represented using a static userdata of type JsonNull 3) Do not use it when input cannot be entirely trusted

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Json.DefaultValueHandling
member.summary: Specifies default value handling options for the .

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.DefaultValueHandling.Include
member.summary: Include members where the member value is the same as the member's default value when serializing objects. Included members are written to JSON. Has no effect when deserializing.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.DefaultValueHandling.Ignore
member.summary: Ignore members where the member value is the same as the member's default value when serializing objects so that it is not written to JSON. This option will ignore all default values (e.g. null for objects and nullable types; 0 for integers, decimals and floating point numbers; and false for booleans). The default value ignored can be changed by placing the on the property.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.DefaultValueHandling.Populate
member.summary: Members with a default value but no JSON will be set to their default value when deserializing.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.DefaultValueHandling.IgnoreAndPopulate
member.summary: Ignore members where the member value is the same as the member's default value when serializing objects and set members to their default value when deserializing.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Json.FloatFormatHandling
member.summary: Specifies float format handling options when writing special floating point numbers, e.g. , and with .

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.FloatFormatHandling.String
member.summary: Write special floating point values as strings in JSON, e.g. "NaN", "Infinity", "-Infinity".

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.FloatFormatHandling.Symbol
member.summary: Write special floating point values as symbols in JSON, e.g. NaN, Infinity, -Infinity. Note that this will produce non-valid JSON.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.FloatFormatHandling.DefaultValue
member.summary: Write special floating point values as the property's default value in JSON, e.g. 0.0 for a property, null for a of property.

member.name: T:Dreamcast.Json.FloatParseHandling
member.summary: Specifies how floating point numbers, e.g. 1.0 and 9.9, are parsed when reading JSON text.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.FloatParseHandling.Double
member.summary: Floating point numbers are parsed to .

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.FloatParseHandling.Decimal
member.summary: Floating point numbers are parsed to .

member.summary: Indicates the method that will be used during deserialization for locating and loading assemblies.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.TypeNameAssemblyFormatHandling.Simple
member.summary: In simple mode, the assembly used during deserialization need not match exactly the assembly used during serialization. Specifically, the version numbers need not match as the LoadWithPartialName method of the class is used to load the assembly.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.TypeNameAssemblyFormatHandling.Full
member.summary: In full mode, the assembly used during deserialization must match exactly the assembly used during serialization. The Load method of the class is used to load the assembly.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.TypeNameHandling.All
member.summary: Always include the .NET type name when serializing.

member.name: F:Dreamcast.Json.TypeNameHandling.Auto
member.summary:
Include the .NET type name when the type of the object being serialized is not the same as its declared type. Note that this doesn't include the root serialized object by default. To include the root object's type name in JSON you must specify a root type object with
or .
